note_models.name: Basic-6b848

fields: The pressure exerted by a vapour that exists in equilibrium with its lliquid.
The temperature that corresponds to the maximum vapour pressure of water at standard atmospheric pressure (101.325kPa), corresponds to a temperature of 100 degrees celcius.

The tendency and measure of the ability of a liquid to go to the vapour phase, expressed as the ratio of the mole fraction in the gas phase to the mole fraction in the liquid phase.

\(K_a=(y_a)/(x_a)\)

The sum of the energies of motion of all \(6.02\times 10^23\) molecules in one gram-mole of the species plys the intramolecular kinetic and ptential energies of all the atoms and subatomic particles, which are quantaties we cannot determine.

H=U+PV

Whre PV represents the flow energy of the fluid (flow work), required to push a fluid and to maintain flow. 


Equal to the system's internal energy plus the product of its pressure and volume. 

For an encolosed system to prevent mass transfer, for processes at constant pressure, the heat absorbed or released equals the change in enthalpy. 

State function that depends only on the prevailing equilibrium state identified by the system's internal energy, pressure and volume. 

Extensive quantitiy. 

Enthalpies comprise a systems internal energy, which is the energy required to create the system plus the amount of work required to make room for it by displacing its environemnt and estabilisng its volume and pressure.

Heat that must be transferred to raise or lower the tempreature of a substance or mixture of substances. 

The proportion of the internal energy of a system associated with the kinetic energy of the molecules. The average velocity and the degree of activity of the molecules are proportional to the temperature. 

The thermal energy which when added to a substance increases its temperateure without a change in state.

When energy passes as work, as heat, or with matter into or out of a system, the system's internal energy changes in accord with the law of conservation of energy.

Law of Conservation of Energy - The total energy of an isolated system remains constant, conserved over time. Energy can neither be created nor destroyed, rather it can only be transformed or transferred from one form to another. 

First Law of Thermodynamics - Although energy assumes many forms, the total quantity of energy is constant, and when energy disappears in one form it appears simultaneously in other forms.

A quantity that is independent of how the substance was prepared. 

e.g. Pressure, volume, temperature, internal energy
Work being added or removed from a system without a change in volume of the system.
The work interaction of the system and surroundings when mass crosses a boundary.

Gas as a collection of molecules (or atoms) in continuous random motion, with average speeds that increase as the temperature is raised.

A gas differs from a liquid in that, except during collisions, the molecules of a gas are widely separated from one another and move in paths that are largely unaffected by intermolecular forces.

The physical state of a sample of a substance, its physical condition, is defined by its
physical properties. Two samples of a substance that have the same physical properties
are in the same state. The state of a pure gas, for example, is specified by giving its
volume, V, amount of substance (number of moles), n, pressure, p, and temperature,
T. However, it has been established experimentally that it is sufficient to specify only
three of these variables, for then the fourth variable is fixed. That is, it is an experimental
fact that each substance is described by an equation of state, an equation that
interrelates these four variables.

P=f(T,V,n)

A boundary is diathermic (thermally conducting) if a change of state is
observed when two objects at different temperatures are brought into contact.

A boundary is adiabatic (thermally insulating)
if no change occurs even though the two objects have different temperatures. A
vacuum flask is an approximation to an adiabatic container.

Thermal equilibrium is established if no change of state occurs when two objects A to B are in
contact through a diathermic boundary.

The zeroth law of thermodynamics states that if two thermodynamic systems are each in thermal equilibrium with a third one, then they are in thermal equilibrium with each other.

Two systems are said to be in the relation of thermal equilibrium if they are linked by a wall permeable only to heat and they do not change over time.

If A is in thermal equilibrium with B and if B is in thermal equilibrium with C, then A is in thermal equilibrium with C .

If a body C, be in thermal equilibrium with two other bodies, A and B, then A and B are in thermal equilibrium with one anothe

A process that occurst with no (appreciable) internal temperature, pressure, or velocity gradients, and therefore no internal flows or viscous dissipation. 

One in wich the net driving force driving it is infinitessimal in size.

A process that can be reversed at any point due too an infinitessimal change in external conditions.

Is never more than minutely removed from equilibrium. (minimal displacement  of the system from internal equilibrium and equilibrium with its surroundings)

Travasses a succession of equilibrium steps.

Frictionless 

Driven by forces whose imbalance is infinitessimal in magnitude.

Proceeds inifinitely slowly. 

When reversed, retraces its path, restoring the initial state of system and surroundings.

Successive removal of small increments at a rate that ensures continuous rise (change).

Transforms the work done by the as into internal energy of the gas. 

Irriversible process.

Intensive variables of an equilibrium system. (Temperature, pressure, specific volume, specific internal energy...)

The value of any intensive variable depends on the equilibrium state of the System and not the path by which the equilibrium state was reached. 

State Variable is an independent variable of a state funciton, like internal energy, enthalpy and entorpy.

The entropy change of any system and its surroundings, considered together, and resulting from any real process, is positive. 

All spontaneous processes that occur in an isolated constant-volume system result in the evolution of the system to a state of equilibrium. 

Approaching zero when the process approaches reversibility. 

\[\inc S_(total)>=0\]

For any process, the process proceeds in such a direction that the total entropy change associated with it is positive. The limiting value is zero, being attained only by a reversible process. 


No process is possible where the total entropy decreases.
Specifies the degree of irriversibility of a process, shows the spontaneous direction of the process.
No state variable can change with time.

The change in internal energy and the change in entropy is zero. This is because both variables are state variables, these being independent of the path. Due to the fact that for a cycle, the initial and final positions are the same, there is no change in the state variables.

A process that occurs with internal temperature, pressure and or velocity gradients so that there are internal flows and or viscous dissipation. 

E.g. Heat conduction process in which a temperature gradient exists.

The tendency of the species to transfer from the liquid (or solid) state to the vapor state.



The higher the vapour pressure of a species, the greater its volatility of the species at the given temperature.

At a given temperature and pressure, a volatile substance is significantly more likely to be found in the vapor phase than in the liquid phase.

Low volatility substance is much more likely to be found in the condensed phase.

The vapor pressure of a species reflects its volatility. 

Generally, the higher the vapor pressure at a given temperature, the greater the volatility of the species at that tempeature. 

\(p*_i (T) = P_total\) at \(T_bp,i\) (At the boiling point the vapour pressure equals the total pressure)

Vapour pressure range from Triple Point to the Critical Point (Existence of both liquid and gas phases)

Vapour Pressure can be estimated/calculated using 
        Clausius-Clapeyron Equation
        Antoine's Equation
        Perry's Handbook
        Wagner-Ambrose's Equation 

Vapor pressure is the pressure exerted by the vapor phase over a liquid surface.


High vapor pressure at room temperature indicates a highly volatile substance, as more particles are present in the vapor phase, the vapor pressure increase. 

The Clausius-Clapeyron equation relates the vapor pressure to temperature and indicates the non-linear relationship. 

At a higher kinetic energy, more particles have sufficient kinetic energy to overcome the intermolecular forces within the liquid phase and can thus escape the surface of the liquid phase, thus increasing the vapor pressure. 

The atmospheric boiling point of a liquid (normal boiling point) is the temperature at which the vapor pressure equals the ambient atmospheric pressure. With an incremental increase in temperature, the vapor pressure becomes sufficient to overcome the atmospheric pressuire and lift the liquid to form vapor bubbles inside the bulk of the substance. 

Bubble formation deeper in the liquid requires a higher temperautre due to the higher fluid pressure, because fluid pressure increases above atmospheric pressure as the depth increases. 

Surface tension of the bubble wall leads to an overpressure in the very small initial bubbles.

Number of state variables (independent intesive variables) that must be specified for a system at equilibrium in order to completely fix the state of each phase of the system.

The number of intensitve variables that can be specififed indepednently for a system at equilibrium is called the degrees of freedom of the system.

Conventional Degrees of Freedom - Specified the number of process variabels (extensive variables) that must be specified for a system before the remaining variabels can be calculated. 

In the Gibbs Phase Rule, the numebr of intesive varibels that must be specified for a system before the remaining intensive variables can be calculated.

Function defined for a system relating several state variables or state quantities, that depend only on the current equilibrium state of the system. 

State functions do not depend on the path by which the system arrived at its present state. 

A state function describes the equilibrium state of a system. 

Internal energy, enthalpy and entropy describe quantitatively an equilibrium state of a thermodynamic system, irrespective of how the system arrived in that state. 

Mechanical work and heat are process quantities or path functions because their values depend on the specfic transition (path) between two equilibrium states.

Static condition in which no change occur in the macroscopic properties of the system with time.

At the microscopic level conditions are  not static.

High density similar to a liquid, but not a liquid, as there exists no separation between the liquid and vapour phases. 

Supercritical fluids transport properties, such as high diffusivities, that are more typical of gases.

Typically transparent and look similar to gases, but they have propperties that are more commonly associated to liquids.

Important Applicaitons 
         Supercritical Fluid Extraction - High densities allow supercritical fluids to act like solvents (replacing some liquids), compounds can be separated by dissolving one or more of them in a supercritical fluid. 
         Carbon dioxide, is the most commonly used solvent. 

Above the critical point - critical pressure and critical temperature.

Endpoint of a phase equilibrium curve. 

Beyond the cirtical pressure and critical temperature the phase boundaries dissapear. 

Subcritical - Liquid and vapour may coexist.

Endpoint of a phase equilibrium curve. 

Tripe Point - Coexistance of three phases.

Critical Point - Only one phase exists.

Above Critical Pressure and Critical Temperature - Supercritical Fluid.

Below Critical Pressure and Above Critical Temperature - Gaseous Phase 

Above Critical Pressure and Below Critical Temperature - Compressible Liquid.

Below Critical Temperature and Critical Pressure and Above the Triple Point Temrpeature - Vapour Phase

All fluids when compared at the same reduced temperature (isotherms) in a graph of compressibility factor (Z) y-axis against reduced pressure (Pr) have approximately the same compressibility factor and all deviate from the ideal gas behaviour to the same degree.

This fact can be used to calculate PVT properties of gases (state variables) for which no Equation of State is available.

Equilibirum between the vapour phase of a pure fluid with its liquid phase.

The equality of the chemical potential, temperature and pressure in both fases

Correlate vapour pressures as a function of temperature. 

Valid over limited temperature ranges.

Equations obtained from regressing experimental data.

Valid over a small temperature and pressure range. (i.e. 0.01 to 2 bars).

Relations should never be used outside the stated temperature limits.

pg 231 Chapter 7.3 Poling

Energy that can be absorbed or released due to a change in the particle number of the species. (in a chemial reaction or phase transition).

Chemical Equilibrium or Phase Equilibrium the total sum of the product of chemical potentials and the stoichiometric coefficients is zero, as the free energy is at a minimum.

A partial molar property (other than volume) of a constituent species in an ideal gas mixture is equal to the corresponding molar property of the species as a pure idea gas at the mixture tempearture but at a pressure equal to its partial pressure in the mixture.

Assumptions 

Steady Flow - Continous flow rate.

Fully Developed

Constant Density (Incompressible Fluid) - Gas where change in presssure is small with regards to total pressure.

Constant Viscosity (Newtonian Fluid) - Acceptable for gases and low molecular weight liquids. 

Constant Temperature - is required as viscosity is temperature dependent, can vary widely with tempearture.

Negligible End Effects - Long pipes are assumed and pressure gradient measured from ends (50-100 diameters from entry and 5-10 diameters from exit).

No Slip Boundary Conditions - Continuum - No0t low pressure gases or very small cappilaries. 

Hagen-Poiseuille Equation 

Relates the volumetric flow rate through a horizontal pipe of circular cross-section to the pipe diameter, pipe length, fluid viscosity and pressure drop.
Constant Volume and Constant Internal Energy

At constant temperature and pressure, chemical reactions are spontanous in the direction of decreasing Gibbs energy.

Extensive property - Dependent on the system size.

Energy is added to a fluid as work, but is transferred from the fluid as heat. Energy is stored, contained within the fluid as internal energy.

Ceaseless motion, whereby all molecules internal to the substance posses kinetic energy of translation, except for monatomic molecules, they also possess kinetic energy of rotation and of internal vibration. 

Potential energy resulting from intermolecular forces.

Internal energy has no concicse thermodynamic definition. It is a thermodynamic primitive. It cannot be direcly measured, there are no internal energy meters. 

The sum of all microscopic forms of energy. Sum of the kinetic and potential energy of molecules.

For an ideal gas, following the equation of state, the specific heat capacity at constant pressure is greater than that at constant volume, as the system under constant pressure is allowed to undergo expansion, for which additional work must be supplied. 

Cp=Cv+R

For ideal gases heat capacities are solely dependent upon temperature, whilst for other substances, these may depend on tempearture and pressure.

Compressor 
{{c1::Primary objective is to increase the pressure of the gas. Density of the gas is considerably incrased. All real compressors, have a consequent increase in discharged temperature and pressure. }}

Pressure and temperature are interrelated in real gases, even for a perfectly revesible (100% efficient process). For Gas expansion, temperature drops. 

Fan and Blower
{{c2::Primary objective is to cause the motion of the gas, pressure change across the machine is very small, sufficient to overcome the resistance to motion of the fluid (overcome downstream pressure drop), the blower discharge pressure is dictated by the downstream pressure drop, the lower the pressure drop, the smaller the power requirement, so the variation of density is negligible and the fluid may be regarded as incompressible.}}

Fan Construction 
{{c3::Deal with constant-density flow and conseuqnelty are very similar, both in construction and operation, to pumps.}}

A gas is assumed to be cryogenic if it can be liquified at or below -150oC or -180oC 

Normal boiling points of the permanant gases (helium, hydrogen, neon, nitrogen, oxygen and normal air), lie below -180oC 

Freon refrigerants, hydrocarbons and other common refrigerants lie above -180oC

Stable, nonflammable, low toxicity gases or liquids which have generally been used as refrigerants and as aerosol propellants.

These include chloroflurohydrocarbons (CFCs)

Fluorocarbon Refrigerants

Thermodynamic temperature scale based on the absolute zero (similarly to Kelvin), but a temperature difference of 1 Rankine is defined equal to a tempreeature difference of 1 Farenheit degrese, rather than the Celcius Degree used on the Kelvin scale.

Rankine scale is analogous to the Kelvin scale

Brine Solution - Salt in water solution with composition ranging from about 3.5% to 26%

An ideal reversible (\(S_gen = 0\)) thermodynamic cycle used in steam power plants. 
Converts heat to mechanical work. 

Water being introduced under pressure (fluid pressure caused by pump) into a boiler, where evaporation takes place, followed by the expansion of the vapor without the loss of heat (adiabatic), ending in condensation.

Introduction to Chemical Engineering Thermodynaics JM Smith Van Ness 

1) Isobaric - steam passess from boiler to the cylinder (constant pressure)
                           Heating of subcooled liquid to its saturation temperautre, vaporisation, and superheating vapor
                           Superheated vapor helps to maintain a high-quality vapor-liquid mixture at the trubine effluent and not damage turbine blades, greater themrodynamic efficiency. Maintain a low moisture content.
                           As long as moisture content is less than 10% erosion problems are not serious.
                           Boiler - Sensible Heat (heating to saturation temperature), latent heat (vaporising liquid), sensible heat (heating to superheated vapor)

2) Reversible, Adiabatic (isentropic) - steam expansion to the condenser pressure
                           Producing wet-exhaust (vapor-liquid equilibrium)

3) Isothermal, Isobaric - Heat is given to the condenser to produce a saturated liquid. 
                           

4) Reversible, Adidabatic, Isentropic pump - Condensate is returned to the boiler using a pump
                            Pumping of the saturated liquid to the pressure of the boiler producing compressed sub-cooled liquid.
                             

Work done is equivelent to the total heat in the steam at the end of the adiabatic expansion subtracted from the total heat in the steam at the begining of the expansion (this is the turbine).

Refrigeration cycles work in the opposite direction of power cycles. 

Natural heat transfer hot --> cold 

Input required to drive heat from low tempeartures to high temperature reservoirs. 



Reversed Carnot Cycle for Refrigeration
Expansion turbine is replaced by an isenthalpic expansion valve (Throtelling Valve), reduces moving parts requirement.

Expansion (Throtelling) Valve used to cool the working fluid (substitutes the need for a Turbine)

Expansion to low temperature and low pressure.

This process avoids cryogenic temperature required for liquifying gases.

Isenthalpic process

Expansion occurs much faster than heat transfer, so opeartion is assumed adiabatic.

Emperical (experimental) law that descirbes how the pressure of a gas tends to increase as the volume of the container decreases.


The absolute pressure exerted by a given mass of an ideal gas is inversely proportional to the volume it occupies if the temperature and amount of gas remain unchanged within a closed system.


Comparing the same substance under two different sets of conditions, the law can be expressed as:


As the volume increases, the pressure decreases in proportion.

The pressure of a given mass of gas varies directly with the absolute temperature of the gas, when the volume is kept constant.




Law of Combining Volumes - The ratio between the volumes of the reactant gasse and the gaseous products can be expressed in simple whole numbers.

At the same temperature and pressure, equal volumes of gas contain equal numbers of molecules.

For a given mass of an ideal gas, the volume and amount (moles) of the gas are directly proportional if the temperature and pressure are constant.



Molar Volume (ideal gas)
When the pressure of a sample is held constant, the temperature, is inversley proportiional to the volume.
proportionality factor that relates the average relative kinetic energy of particles in a gas with the thermodynamic temperature of the gas.
Work due to Expansion and Contraction

Work of compression or exspansion of a gas caused by the differential displacement of a piston in a cylinder.

Work done on the system (negative sign), whereby work done by the system (positive sign). The force exerted by the piston on the fluid is equal to the product of the piston area and the pressure of the fluid. 

The displacement of the piston is equal to the total volume change of the fluid divided by the area of the piston. 

By convention work is regarded as positive when the displacement is in the same direction as the applied force and negative when they are in opposite directions.

Joule Thomson process (constant enthalpy process) isenthalpic. 

Joule Thomson effect is achieved by allowing a gas to expand through a throtelling device, usually a valve.

The affect applies to the Linde Technique.

The cooling effect is used to liquify a gas.
       A gas must be below the inversion temperature for the gas to be liquified by the Linde cycle.
                The gas must first be cooled below its inversion temperature.

The inversrsion temperature where  
                                              is found experimentally (emperically)

 with units 

All real gases have an inversion point at which the value of the Joule Thomson coefficient changes sign. The temperaure of the inversion depends on the pressure of the gas before expansion. 

The joule-thomson effect avoids cryogenic temperatures required to liquify gases.

Expansion (throttle valve), the always decreases (is negative) for an expansion.

Liquifaction of natural gases (LNG) - requires the cooling of the has to below its boiling-point temperature, however, this would require refrigeration equipment capable of producing very low temperatures. 






What is commonly done is to start the gas at:

1) low pressure

2) compress it to higher pressure  (which increases the tempreature since work is done on the gas)

3) cool the high-temperature gas at the constant high pressure 

4) Expand it to low pressure and low temperature using isenthalpic Joule-Thomson expansion.
              Produces a  liquid-vapor mixture.

This way the cooling is done at higher temperautre (and pressure), so that low-temperature refrigeration is not needed. 

Vapour and liquid are separated in a flash drum (an insulated, constant-pressure container).

Vapour separated using the flash drum can be recirculated, passing through a heat exchanger and further cooling the gas, prior to entering the throtelling valve, increasing vapour fraction. (cool high-pressure gas upstream of the throttle valve and then return to the compressor so that gas does not escape to the atmosphere).

An isentropic process is an idealised thermodynamic process that is both adiabatic and reversible, with no entropy of generation. The work transferred to the system is frictionless and there is no transfer of heat or matter.

The isentropic assumption is only applicable with ideal cycles. Real cycles have inherent lossess dude to compressor and turbine inefficiencies and the 2nd law of thermodynamics. 

However, the isentropic assumption is an adequate approximation for many calculation purposes. 




Although the entropy of the system does not increase, the entropy of the Universe will increase, it is as if the systems entropy is remvoed at the same rate as the entropy is generated, leading to an isentropic assumption, which is physically impossible to achieve.

Reference: pg 162 of Fundamentals of Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics 

The entropy, enthalpy, temperature, density and other parameters are all state functions (variables), this means that they are independent of the path taken, depenending solely on the initial and final state of the system. 

We can use the fact that entropy is a state funciton (variable) on an Open-System (steady-state) as with a compressor, isenthalpic valve  (expansion/throtelling valve), turbine...
